It consists of a collapsed layer composed of the access and the distribution layer, and a second layer composed of the core layer.
The primary function of the collapsed layer is to provide network access to the user.

questionText: A network administrator is considering whether PoE features are required in a specific network installation. Which option provides valid information about PoE?
explanation: The Power over Ethernet (PoE) feature allows the switch to deliver power to a device over the existing Ethernet cabling. This feature can be used by IP phones and some wireless access points, allowing them to be installed anywhere that there is an Ethernet cable. The Cisco Catalyst 2960-C and 3560-C Series compact switches support the PoE pass-through feature. It allows a network administrator to power PoE devices connected to the switch, as well as the switch itself, by drawing power from certain upstream switches.

answerChoices.Text: The PoE pass-through feature is only supported by the Cisco Catalyst 3560-C Series compact switch model or higher.
Any switch port can be configured with IOS commands to function as a PoE port.
PoE allows the switch to deliver power to a device over the existing power grid.
It can be used by IP phones, allowing them to be installed anywhere that there is an Ethernet cable.

questionText: How are network data transmissions calculated?
explanation: Bandwidth is the capacity at which a medium can carry data. Throughput is usually lower than the bandwidth because of a number of factors like type and amount of traffic. Goodput is throughput minus traffic overhead for establishing sessions, acknowledgments, encapsulation, and retransmitted bits.

questionText: Refer to the exhibit. A corporate network is using NTP to synchronize the time across devices. What can be determined from the displayed output?
explanation: The show ntp status command displays that Router03 is now a stratum 2 device synchronized with the NTP server at 209.165.220.225 and can provide NTP service to other devices in the network. The clock offset is only 7.0883 milliseconds, not 7.0883 seconds.

answerChoices.Text: The interface on Router03 that connects to the time sever has the IPv4 address 209.165.200.225.
Router03 is a stratum 2 device that can provide NTP service to other devices in the network.
The time on Router03 may not be reliable because it is offset by more than 7 seconds to the time server.
Router03 time is synchronized to a stratum 2 time server.

questionText: A user is reading a book from the website https://www.books-info.com/author50/book1.html#page150. Which term is used to describe the component www.books-info.com/author50/book1.html?
explanation:
In the website link https://www.books-info.com/author50/book1.html#page150, different terms are used to describe its components:
* Protocol – https
* Fragment – #page150
* Uniform Resource Name (URN) – www.books-info.com/author50/book1.html
* Uniform Resource Locator (URL) – https://www.books-info.com/author50/book1.html
* Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) – https://www.books-info.com/author50/book1.html#page150

questionText:
A network engineer is configuring a Cisco switch when this message is displayed.
%LINK-3-UPDOWN: Interface Port-channel1, changed state to up
What is the Syslog severity level of this message?
explanation: The message is Syslog severity level 3, which denotes an error condition.

questionText: Two recent networking graduates from a local college have just been hired by a communication company to work on various network cabling projects throughout the state. Why would the company consider using fiber-optic cabling in long-haul networks?
explanation: Fiber-optic cabling is now being used in four types of industry: enterprise networks (backbone cabling applications and interconnecting infrastructure devices); fiber-to-the-home (always-on broadband services to homes and small businesses); long-haul networks (connecting countries to countries and cities to cities); and submarine cable networks (reliable high-speed, high-capacity solutions capable of surviving in harsh undersea environments at up to transoceanic distances).

answerChoices.Text: to provide high capacity solutions for teleworkers
to provide always-on broadband services to customers in homes and small businesses
to provide backbone cabling to applications and interconnecting infrastructure devices for customers
to provide connectivity between countries or between cities

questionText: A technician is reviewing a report of slowness during peak traffic periods and is looking at performance on a particular switch. What should the technician be aware of about memory buffering on a switch?
explanation: When shared memory buffering method is used, the frames in the buffer are dynamically linked to the destination port, enabling a packet to be received on one port and then transmitted on another port without moving it to a different queue. This buffering method deposits all frames into a common memory buffer shared by all switch ports, and the amount of buffer memory required by a port is dynamically allocated. In port-based memory, it is possible for a single frame to delay the transmission of all the frames in memory because of a busy destination port.

answerChoices.Text: The port-based memory method is more appropriate to asymmetric switching.
If shared memory is used, a single frame can delay the transmission of all others in memory because of a busy destination port.
The amount of buffer memory required by a port is dynamically allocated when port-based memory is used.
Shared memory allows traffic received on one port to be transmitted to another port without moving the data to a different queue.

questionText: Data is being sent from a source PC to a destination server. Which three statements correctly describe the function of TCP or UDP in this situation? (Choose three.)
explanation: Layer 4 port numbers identify the application or service which will handle the data. The source port number is added by the sending device and will be the destination port number when the requested information is returned. Layer 4 segments are encapsulated within IP packets. UDP, not TCP, is used when low overhead is needed. A source IP address, not a TCP source port number, identifies the sending host on the network. Destination port numbers are specific ports that a server application or service monitors for requests.

answerChoices.Text: The source port field identifies the running application or service that will handle data returning to the PC.
The TCP process running on the PC randomly selects the destination port when establishing a session with the server.
UDP segments are encapsulated within IP packets for transport across the network.
The UDP destination port number identifies the application or service on the server which will handle the data.
TCP is the preferred protocol when a function requires lower network overhead.
The TCP source port number identifies the sending host on the network.

questionText: In computer network communications which data transfer process does the application layer protocol FTP use?
explanation: FTP uses a client-server process. Gnutella is a peer-to-peer protocol. Server message block is a protocol used to share structured network resources.

questionText: A Cisco switch and a Juniper switch use a Layer-2 discovery protocol to share information about each other. Which protocol are they likely using?
explanation: Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP) is a vendor-neutral Layer-2 discovery protocol used by various networking devices, including those from Cisco, Juniper, and most other vendors. Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP), on the other hand, is Cisco proprietary (although it has been implemented by a few other vendors).

questionText: Which of the following commands doubles the frequency at which a device sends CDP messages?
explanation: The cdp timer command sets the frequency at which CDP messages are sent. The default timer is 60 seconds, so setting it to 30 seconds would double the frequency.

questionText: By default, how many LLDP messages can a device miss from its neighbor before removing the neighbor from its LLDP neighbor table?
explanation: The default hold time for LLDP is 120 seconds, and LLDP messages are sent every 30 seconds by default. Therefore, a device can miss up to 4 LLDP messages (120 seconds / 30 seconds per message) before it removes the neighbor from its table.

questionText: Which command allows the device to control how long its LLDP neighbors wait before removing its entry from their neighbor tables?
explanation: The lldp holdtime command sets the amount of time a device’s neighbors should hold information before discarding it. This time is communicated in LLDP messages sent by the device.

questionText: Which command globally enables CDP on a device?
explanation: The cdp run command—issued in global config mode—globally enables CDP on a Cisco device. This command is required to activate CDP if it has been previously disabled (although CDP is globally enabled by default).

questionText: You issue show cdp neighbors on R1. SW1’s entry shows Local Intrfce: Gig 0/0 and Port ID: 0/1. Which of the following statements is true?
explanation: In the output of show cdp neighbors, the Local Intrfce column indicates the interface of this device (R1), and the Port ID column indicates the interface of the neighboring device (SW1).

answerChoices.Text: R1 G0/0 is connected to SW1 G0/1.
R1 G0/1 is connected to SW1 G0/0.

questionText: Which of the following statements about LLDP is false?
explanation: LLDP doesn’t require an IP address on an interface to send (or receive) messages—the same applies to CDP. CDP and LLDP are Layer-2 discovery protocols; they function even on interfaces that don’t have Layer-3 IP addresses.

answerChoices.Text: An interface must have an IP address to send LLDP messages.
LLDP Tx and Rx can be controlled separately.
LLDP is disabled on Cisco devices by default.
Any vendor can implement LLDP on its devices.

questionText: Which command(s) can be used to disable LLDP on an interface?
explanation: To completely disable LLDP on an interface, both transmission and reception of LLDP messages must be turned off. You can do this with the no lldp transmit and no lldp receive commands in interface config mode.

answerChoices.Text: no lldp transmit and no lldp receive

questionText: Which command manually configures a Cisco device’s clock?
explanation: The command to set the software clock is clock set hh:mm:ss month day year. Note that the month and day arguments can be reversed: January 19 and 19 January are both valid.

questionText: Which kind of NTP server operates as both an NTP client and server?
explanation: A secondary NTP server operates both as an NTP client (synchronizing its time with a more authoritative server) and as a server (providing the time to clients of its own).

questionText: R1 is an NTP client. The output of show ntp associations on R1 shows st: 3. What does this output mean?
explanation: The show ntp associations command lists the device’s NTP associations—NTP servers that it learns the time from. The st column lists the association’s NTP stratum. In this case, the value of 3 means that R1 learns the time from a server whose NTP stratum is 3.

answerChoices.Text: R1 has a total of three NTP associations.
R1 learns the time from a server whose NTP stratum is 3.

questionText: What is the default NTP stratum level of a Cisco router that has been configured with ntp master?
explanation: When a Cisco router is configured with ntp master without specifying a stratum level, it defaults to stratum 8.

questionText: Which of the following statements are true? (select two)
explanation: The read-only (RO) community string only allows the NMS to read information from the managed device with Get, GetNext, and GetBulk; it can’t modify the managed device with Set messages. The read-write (RW) community string, on the other hand, allows Get, GetNext, GetBulk, and Set messages.

answerChoices.Text: The RO community string allows the NMS to send Get/GetNext/GetBulk and Set messages.
The RW community string allows the NMS to send Get/GetNext/GetBulk and Set messages.
The RW community string allows the NMS to send Set messages only.
The RO community string allows the NMS to send Get/GetNext/GetBulk messages only.

questionText: Which of the following statements accurately describes the effect of the logging buffered notifications command?
explanation: logging buffered notifications enables logging at severity level 5. However, it doesn’t only enable logging of messages of severity level 5; it enables logging of all messages with a severity level of 5 and numerically lower (more severe). So, the command enables logging of messages of severity levels 0–5.

answerChoices.Text: Logs of severity level 5 and numerically higher will be logged.
Logs of severity level 5 and numerically lower will be logged.
Logs of severity level 5 will be logged.

questionText: Which severity levels will be logged to the console line as a result of the logging console 2 command? (select three)
explanation: The logging console 2 command configures the console to log messages with a severity of critical (level 2) and numerically lower, which includes alerts (level 1) and emergencies (level 0).

questionText: Which QoS feature modifies specific fields in the Layer-2 and Layer-3 headers to facilitate the categorization of messages?
explanation: Marking modifies fields in Layer-2 (CoS) and Layer-3 (DSCP) headers, making the classification of messages for QoS much simpler.

questionText: Which of the following markings indicates a high priority and a high drop precedence?
explanation: AF43 (Assured Forwarding class 4, drop precedence 3) indicates high priority but also a high likelihood of being dropped in times of congestion. AF defines four priority classes (1–4) and three drop precedence values (1–3).

questionText: Which QoS feature drops or re-marks traffic that exceeds the configured rate limit?
explanation: Policing drops or re-marks traffic that exceeds a configured rate limit, enforcing a strict bandwidth limit without buffering.

questionText: Which marking is typically used for voice call traffic?
explanation: The Expedited Forwarding (EF) marking is typically used for voice traffic to ensure low delay, jitter, and loss by treating these packets with high priority. When using LLQ, packets marked with EF are typically queued in the priority queue.

questionText: Which marking is typically used for best effort traffic?
explanation: Default Forwarding (DF) is the default marking for best effort traffic, indicating no special treatment or priority.

questionText: Which command guarantees power to a PoE-enabled device connected to the port?
explanation: The power inline static command reserved a fixed amount of power for the specified port, ensuring the device connected to the port receives power.

questionText: Which layer of a three-tier LAN is most likely to implement security services such as Port Security, DHCP Snooping, and DAI?
explanation: The access layer in a three-tier LAN is usually responsible for implementing security services like Port Security, DHCP Snooping, and Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI). This layer directly interacts with end-user devices, making it a critical point for enforcing security policies.

questionText: Which layers are combined in a two-tier LAN? (select two)
explanation: In a two-tier (collapsed core) LAN architecture, the distribution and core layers are collapsed into a single layer. This simplifies the architecture and is commonly used in smaller LANs where a separate core layer is not necessary.

questionText: In a three-tier LAN, where is the border between Layers 2 and 3 usually located?
explanation: In a three-tier LAN, the distribution layer usually serves as the border between Layers 2 and 3 of the TCP/IP Model. End hosts use SVIs on the distribution switches as their default gateways, and the distribution switches use a routing protocol like OSPF to share routing information with each other and the core switches.

questionText: In a three-tier LAN, which switches are most likely to support PoE?
explanation: The access layer is where end hosts that might require Power over Ethernet (PoE), such as IP phones and wireless access points, connect to the network. Therefore, access switches are most likely to support PoE.

questionText: In a three-tier LAN, which layer is focused on speed and reliability, avoiding CPU-intensive operations?
explanation: The Core layer in a three-tier LAN is focused on providing fast and reliable transport of packets across the LAN. Core switches typically don’t implement CPU-intensive operations like security features and QoS marking that would slow down the forwarding of packets.

questionText: In a three-tier LAN, where is QoS marking most often performed?
explanation: QoS marking should generally be performed close to a packet’s source, simplifying the classification process for the rest of the packet’s journey. The access layer is where end hosts connect to the network, so marking is often performed at this layer.

questionText: Which of the following statements about spine-leaf architecture is true?
explanation: In a spine-leaf architecture, every leaf switch connects to every spine switch, but leaf switches don’t connect to other leaf switches, and spine switches don’t connect to other spine switches. End hosts—typically servers—connect to leaf switches, not spine switches.

answerChoices.Text: Every leaf switch is connected to every other leaf switch.
Every leaf switch is connected to every spine switch.
Every spine switch is connected to every other spine switch
End hosts connect to spine switches.

questionText: Which of the following are benefits of spine-leaf architecture? (select two)
explanation: Different servers in a spine-leaf architecture are a consistent number of hops away from each other, providing consistent and predictable latency between servers. Scaling a spine-leaf LAN is simple: just add more leaf switches and connect each new leaf switch to each spine switch.

answerChoices.Text: Consistent and predictable latency between servers
Simple scalability by adding more leaf switches

questionText: Which type of network is most likely to benefit from spine-leaf architecture?
explanation: Data center LANs are most likely to benefit from spine-leaf architecture due to its high scalability, predictable latency, and efficient handling of the east-west traffic that is common in modern data centers.

questionText: Which of the following statements about SOHO networks is true?

answerChoices.Text: SOHO networks typically use a two-tier architecture.
SOHO networks require redundant internet connections.
SOHO networks require separate WAN and internet connections.
SOHO networks’ needs are often met by a single wireless router.

questionText: Which term refers to the phenomenon of an electromagnetic wave bending when it passes from one medium to another one with a different density?
explanation: Refraction is the bending of an electromagnetic wave as it passes from one medium into another with a different density. This can affect wireless signals as they pass through various materials.

questionText: Which term refers to the erratic spreading out of an electromagnetic wave as the result of encountering a surface or medium with irregularities?
explanation: Scattering occurs when an electromagnetic wave encounters a surface or medium with irregularities, causing the wave to spread out erratically. This can lead to signal degradation in wireless networks.

questionText: Which of the following are not 802.11 management messages?

questionText: Which three statements accurately describe Layer 2 Ethernet switches? (Choose three.)
explanation:
Microsegmentation is a network design (functionality) where each workstation or device on a network gets its own dedicated segment (collision domain) to the switch. Each network device gets the full bandwidth of the segment and does not have to share the segment with other devices. Microsegmentation reduces and can even eliminate collisions because each segment is its own collision domain.
Note: Microsegmentation decreases the number of collisions but it increases the number of collision domains.

answerChoices.Text: Spanning Tree Protocol allows switches to automatically share VLAN information.
Establishing VLANs increases the number of broadcast domains.
Switches that are configured with VLANs make forwarding decisions based on both Layer 2 and Layer 3 address information.
Microsegmentation decreases the number of collisions on the network.

In a properly functioning network with redundant switched paths, each switched segment will contain one root bridge with all its ports in the forwarding state. All other switches in that broadcast domain will have only one root port.
If a switch receives a frame for an unknown destination, it uses ARP to resolve the address.

questionText: Refer to the exhibit.
explanation:
Basically, a collision domain is a network segment that allows normal network traffic to flow back and forth. In the old days of hubs, this meant you had a lot of collisions, and the old CSMA/CD would be working overtime to try to get those packets re-sent every time there was a collision on the wire (since Ethernet allows only one host to be transmitting at once without there being a traffic jam). With switches, you break up collision domains by switching packets bound for other collision domains. These days, since we mostly use switches to connect computers to the network, you generally have one collision domain to a PC.
Broadcast domains are exactly what they imply: they are network segments that allow broadcasts to be sent across them. Since switches and bridges allow for broadcast traffic to go unswitched, broadcasts can traverse collision domains freely. Routers, however, don’t allow broadcasts through by default, so when a broadcast hits a router (or the perimeter of a VLAN), it doesn’t get forwarded. The simple way to look at it is this way: switches break up collision domains, while routers (and VLANs) break up collision domains and broadcast domains. Also, a broadcast domain can contain multiple collision domains, but a collision domain can never have more than one broadcast domain associated with it.
Collision Domain: A group of Ethernet or Fast Ethernet devices in a CSMA/CD LAN that are connected by repeaters and compete for access on the network. Only one device in the collision domain may transmit at any one time, and the other devices in the domain listen to the network in order to avoid data collisions. A collision domain is sometimes referred to as an Ethernet segment.
Broadcast Domain: Broadcasting sends a message to everyone on the local network (subnet). An example for Broadcasting would be DHCP Request from a Client PC. The Client is asking for a IP Address, but the client does not know how to reach the DHCP Server. So the client sends a DHCP Discover packet to EVERY PC in the local subnet (Broadcast). But only the DHCP Server will answer to the Request.
How to count them?
Broadcast Domain:
No matter how many hosts or devices are connected together, if they are connected with a repeater, hub, switch or bridge, all these devices are in ONE Broadcast domain (assuming a single VLAN). A Router is used to separate Broadcast-Domains (we could also call them Subnets – or call them VLANs). So, if a router stands between all these devices, we have TWO broadcast domains.
Collision Domain:
Each connection from a single PC to a Layer 2 switch is ONE Collision domain. For example, if 5 PCs are connected with separate cables to a switch, we have 5 Collision domains. If this switch is connected to another switch or a router, we have one collision domain more.
If 5 Devices are connected to a Hub, this is ONE Collision Domain. Each device that is connected to a Layer 1 device (repeater, hub) will reside in ONE single collision domain.

answerChoices.Text: The number of collision domains would remain the same.
The number of collision domains would decrease.
The number of collision domains would increase.
The number of broadcast domains would remain the same.
The number of broadcast domains would decrease.
The number of broadcast domains would increase.

questionText: Which of the following accurately describes the difference between TCP and UDP protocols in the TCP/IP model?
explanation:
This question assesses the fundamental differences between TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and UDP (User Datagram Protocol), both Transport Layer protocols.

**TCP (Transmission Control Protocol): Connection-Oriented and Reliable**
- **Connection-Oriented:** Establishes a dedicated, virtual connection using a three-way handshake before data transmission.
- **Reliable Data Delivery:** Ensures data integrity and order through mechanisms like segment numbering, acknowledgements (ACKs), retransmissions for lost data, flow control (windowing), and congestion control. It's suitable for applications where data accuracy is paramount (e.g., web browsing, email, file transfer).

**UDP (User Datagram Protocol): Connectionless and Unreliable**
- **Connectionless:** Sends data datagrams without establishing a prior connection or handshake.
- **Unreliable Data Delivery:** Provides a "best-effort" delivery service with minimal overhead. It does not guarantee delivery, order, or error correction at the protocol level. It's suitable for applications where speed and low latency are more critical than guaranteed delivery (e.g., streaming media, online gaming, VoIP, DNS queries).

Therefore, **Option C** correctly states that TCP is connection-oriented and reliable, while UDP is connectionless and unreliable.

answerChoices.Text: TCP is a connectionless protocol that provides reliable data delivery, while UDP is a connection-oriented protocol that provides unreliable data delivery.
TCP is a connection-oriented protocol that provides unreliable data delivery, while UDP is a connectionless protocol that provides reliable data delivery.
TCP is a connection-oriented protocol that provides reliable data delivery, while UDP is a connectionless protocol that provides unreliable data delivery.
TCP and UDP are both connection-oriented protocols, but TCP provides reliable delivery while UDP does not.

questionText: Which of the following statements are TRUE regarding the characteristics of fiber optic cabling compared to copper cabling in networking? (Choose TWO)
explanation:
Comparing fiber optic and copper cabling:

- **Fiber optic cabling is immune to electromagnetic interference (EMI) and radio frequency interference (RFI).** (TRUE) Fiber uses light pulses, not electrical signals, so it's unaffected by electrical noise.
- **Fiber optic cabling is more secure as it is much harder to tap and eavesdrop on compared to copper cabling.** (TRUE) Physically tapping fiber is difficult and often detectable, unlike copper.

- Fiber optic cabling is generally *more expensive* to install and maintain than copper (FALSE).
- Copper cabling typically supports *lower bandwidth and shorter distances* than fiber (FALSE).
- Copper cabling is *not generally more suitable* for outdoor deployments; both can be constructed for outdoor use, but fiber has advantages like electrical immunity (FALSE).

answerChoices.Text: Fiber optic cabling is generally less expensive to install and maintain than copper cabling.
Fiber optic cabling is immune to electromagnetic interference (EMI) and radio frequency interference (RFI).
Copper cabling typically supports higher bandwidth and longer distances than fiber optic cabling.
Fiber optic cabling is more secure as it is much harder to tap and eavesdrop on compared to copper cabling.
Copper cabling is generally more suitable for outdoor deployments due to its greater durability and resistance to environmental factors.

questionText: What is the primary purpose of hello packets in routing protocols?
explanation:
**Hello packets** are small, periodic messages exchanged between routers in many routing protocols (e.g., OSPF, EIGRP). Their primary purpose is to:

- **Discover and maintain neighbor relationships:** Routers use hello packets to detect directly connected neighbors, establish adjacencies, and monitor their liveness. If hello packets stop arriving from a neighbor within a configured hold time, that neighbor is considered down.

While hello packets are part of the process that leads to routing table updates and shortest path calculations, they do not perform those functions directly.

answerChoices.Text: To verify the integrity of data
To discover and maintain neighbor relationships

questionText: Which technology allows multiple Cisco switches to operate as a single logical switch?
explanation:
**Cisco StackWise** is a proprietary technology that enables multiple physical Cisco Catalyst switches to be interconnected (stacked) and managed as a single logical switch. This provides:

- **Simplified management:** A single management interface for the entire stack.
- **High availability/redundancy:** If one switch in the stack fails, the others continue operating.
- **Increased port density:** More ports available from a single logical entity.

- **EtherChannel** bundles multiple physical links into one logical link for bandwidth/redundancy, but doesn't combine switches into a single logical device.
- **VTP (VLAN Trunking Protocol)** manages VLAN configuration synchronization across switches, not physical stacking.
- **Spanning Tree** prevents Layer 2 loops, not logical switch aggregation.

questionText: Which of the following Power over Ethernet (PoE) standards provides the MOST power to connected devices?
explanation:
The IEEE 802.3bt standard, also known as PoE++ or 4PPoE, is the latest and most powerful Power over Ethernet (PoE) standard. It can deliver significantly more power to connected devices than previous standards.

- **802.3af (PoE):** Up to 15.4W at the source, 12.95W available at the device.
- **802.3at (PoE+):** Up to 30W at the source, 25.5W available at the device.
- **802.3bt (PoE++ or 4PPoE):** Provides up to **90W** at the source, with a maximum of **71.3W available at the device** by utilizing all four pairs of twisted-pair cabling. This is the highest power option listed.
- **802.11ac:** This is a wireless networking standard, not a PoE standard.

questionText: Which of the following statements correctly describe differences between Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP) and Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP)? (Select all that apply.)
explanation:
CDP and LLDP are Layer 2 protocols for device discovery:

- **CDP is a Cisco proprietary protocol, whereas LLDP is an IEEE standard.** (True) CDP is Cisco-specific; LLDP (802.1AB) is open.
- **LLDP can be used in multi-vendor environments, while CDP is generally limited to Cisco devices.** (True) Due to its open standard nature, LLDP offers interoperability.
- **Both protocols operate at Layer 2 and advertise device information, but LLDP supports additional capabilities such as Power over Ethernet (PoE) management.** (True) LLDP-MED extends LLDP for multimedia and PoE details.

- Neither CDP nor LLDP provides inherent **encryption for secure device discovery** (Option D is false); they transmit information in plaintext.

answerChoices.Text: CDP is a Cisco proprietary protocol, whereas LLDP is an IEEE standard.
LLDP can be used in multi-vendor environments, while CDP is generally limited to Cisco devices.
Both protocols operate at Layer 2 and advertise device information, but LLDP supports additional capabilities such as Power over Ethernet (PoE) management.
CDP provides encryption for secure device discovery, while LLDP does not.

questionText: Which protocol is considered connection-oriented and ensures reliable data delivery?
explanation:
At the Transport Layer of the OSI model, two primary protocols are used:

- **TCP (Transmission Control Protocol):** 
    - **Connection-oriented:** Establishes a connection (three-way handshake) before data transfer.
    - **Reliable data delivery:** Guarantees delivery, order, and error correction through sequence numbers, acknowledgements, retransmissions, and flow/congestion control. Used for applications requiring high data integrity (e.g., HTTP, FTP, SSH).

- **UDP (User Datagram Protocol):** Connectionless and unreliable, providing best-effort delivery with lower overhead. Used for applications where speed is paramount and some data loss is acceptable (e.g., VoIP, streaming).

Therefore, **TCP** is the connection-oriented and reliable protocol.

questionText: Which of the following statements accurately describe characteristics of a broadcast domain? (Select all that apply.)
explanation:
A **broadcast domain** is a network segment where any broadcast frame sent by one device is received by all other devices within that same segment. Key characteristics:

- **A broadcast domain includes all devices that receive broadcast frames sent by any member of the domain.** (True)
- **Routers, by default, separate broadcast domains.** (True) Routers do not forward broadcast traffic between interfaces.
- **VLANs can be used to create separate broadcast domains within a single switch.** (True) Each VLAN is its own broadcast domain.
- **All devices in a broadcast domain must be on the same IP subnet.** (True) IP broadcast addresses are tied to the subnet mask, so devices in the same broadcast domain share the same logical IP network.

answerChoices.Text: A broadcast domain includes all devices that receive broadcast frames sent by any member of the domain.
Routers, by default, separate broadcast domains.
VLANs can be used to create separate broadcast domains within a single switch.
All devices in a broadcast domain must be on the same IP subnet. Correct Answers: A, B, C, and D

questionText: At which layer of the OSI model does the Internet Protocol (IP) primarily operate?
explanation:
The OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model has seven layers, each with distinct responsibilities.

- The **Internet Protocol (IP)** primarily operates at the **Network layer (Layer 3)**.
- At this layer, IP is responsible for logical addressing (IP addresses) and routing of data packets across different networks (inter-networking).
- Routers operate at Layer 3 to forward packets based on IP addresses and routing tables.

- **Data Link layer (Layer 2)** handles MAC addressing and frame forwarding within a local segment (e.g., Ethernet).
- **Transport layer (Layer 4)** manages end-to-end communication and reliability (e.g., TCP, UDP).
- **Application layer (Layer 7)** provides network services directly to end-user applications (e.g., HTTP, FTP).

questionText: Which tasks can be accomplished by using the command history feature? (Choose two.)
explanation: The history feature in Cisco IOS allows a user to recall previously entered commands within the current session. The size of the command history buffer can also be adjusted from its default value.

answerChoices.Text: View a list of commands entered in a previous session.
Recall up to 15 command lines by default.
Set the command history buffer size.
Save command lines in a log file for future reference.

questionText: If one end of an Ethernet connection is configured for full duplex and the other end of the connection is configured for half duplex, where would late collisions be observed?
explanation: A duplex mismatch is a common configuration error. The half-duplex end will expect collisions as a normal part of operation, but when it detects traffic while it is sending, it will register a collision. Because the full-duplex end does not perform carrier sense before transmitting, collisions will occur late (after the first 64 bytes). These late collisions will be detected on the half-duplex end.

answerChoices.Text: on both ends of the connection
on the full-duplex end of the connection
on the half-duplex end of the connection

questionText: What is the minimum Ethernet frame size that will not be discarded by the receiver as a runt frame?
explanation: The minimum Ethernet frame size is 64 bytes. Frames smaller than 64 bytes are considered collision fragments or runt frames and are discarded.
